Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Praxair Distribution, Inc. (PDI) is committed to operating in a safe and environmentally sound manner and being a responsible member of the community by making safety information available to the community.  Safety is a top priority at PDI as reflected in its proactive planning, state-of-the-art equipment, employee training, and its coordination with the Contra Costa County Health Services Department (CCCHSD) to prevent accidental releases from occurring and instituting controls to rapidly mitigate a potential release if it does occur.  Risk management planning has been initiated at the facility's inception.  A Hazardous Materials Management Plan (HMMP) was submitted to the CCCHSD in 2002. The HMMP included a hazardous materials inventory, emergency response plan, evacuation plan and planned employee training.

Facility Description

PDI specializes in the distribution of industrial and medical gases (NAICS Code 422690, SIC Code 5169).  The PDI facility at 1930 Loveridge Road, Pittsburg, California (Figure 1) will be a compressed gas distribution center with operations commencing in February 2003.  The plant, occupying approximately 6.3 acres, is a state-of-the art facility constructed in 2002. PDI places a high priority on safety and has had no chemical accidents or releases with offsite consequences in the last five years. Access to the manufacturing and office building is strictly controlled through a chain link fence and a security alarm system. The plant is located off Loveridge Road and California Avenue in Pittsburg near Highway 4.  The surrounding area is used for industrial manufacturing and commercial warehousing activities.  The nearest body of water is the San Joaquin River to the North.  Residences are located 1/4-mile to 1-mile south and west of the site.

Regulated Substances and CalARP Program Levels

PDI uses a number of chemicals that, depending on the quantities handled, are potentially

subject to the following regulations: 
-Federal Risk Management Program (RMP) regulations (Title 40, Code of Federal Regulations, Part 68), also known as the federal Accidental Release Prevention Program
-California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Health & Safety Code, Davison 20, and California Code of Regulations (CCR) Title 19, Division 2
-Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard (29 CFR, 1910.119)
Hydrogen will be stored in excess of the applicable threshold quantities (TQs) for the CalARP Program (See Table 1). Planning requirements for regulated substances are defined in a three-tier program (Programs 1 through 3) based upon: The potential for off-site consequences associated with a worst-case accidental release, accident history; and, applicability of the OSHA PSM Standard. 

Program 1 processes are those with no public receptors within the endpoint distance from a worst-case release and with no accidents with offsite consequences (deaths, injuries or requiring response or restoration activities for an environmental receptor) during the past five years.  Program 2 processes are those not eligible for Program 1 or subject to Program 3 requirements.  Processes ineligible for Program 1 and subject to OSHA PSM or California OSHA programs; or that are described by one of ten specified NAICS codes, are placed in Program 3.  Since this new plant has no accident history, the Offsite Consequence Analysis (OCA) and applicability of OSHA PSM will determine the Program Level.  The local administering agency (AA) for the CalARP Program is the CCCHSD.  This Risk Management Plan (RMP) has been prepared using the CCHSD CalARP Program Guidance Document (CCHSD 1998). 

Process Descriptions

Liquid hydrogen is received at the southwest side of the distribution facility via truck trailer rig (Figure 2).  The liquid hydrogen is offloaded into a cryogenic storage tank using pressure differential to transfer t

he liquid from the truck into the storage tank through a closed loop system.  Process flow diagrams and piping and instrumentation diagrams are present on site. Liquid hydrogen from the storage tank is maintained at a low temperature to maintain a constant pressure in the system.  Parallel pumps are used to boost the pressure to approximately 2000 psi and transfer liquid hydrogen to an ambient vaporizer where the liquid is evaporated.  High-pressure hydrogen gas from the vaporizer is then piped to tubular gas receivers, a cylinder-filling machine or to tube trailers.  Excess hydrogen in vented through a stack. The processes involving ammonia, chlorine and TCS are receiving, unloading/loading and shipping.

Program Levels
Based on the potential for offsite consequences and comparison with TQs for OSHA PSM hydrogen  would be regulated under Program Level 3.

The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

This RMP fulfills Cal-ARP program requirements for the facility and contains process hazard analyses (PHAs), an Offsite Consequence Analysis (OCA) and a Prevention Program including all required prevention program elements.  These elements include the following: Management System, Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps, Process Safety Information, PHA, Operating Procedures, Training, Mechanical Integrity, Management of Change, Compliance Audits, Incident Investigation, Employee Participation, Hot Work Permit, and Contractors.  The facilities CalARP management system is shown on Figure 7.  PDI has systematically examined and identified hazards associated with the operation of the liquid hydrogen gas cylinders.  PDI performed a HAZOP on the liquid hydrogen system in 2002.


The Five Year Accident History

This newly commissioned plant (February 2003) has no accident history of accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.  The compilation of this information satisfies the requirements of Section 2750.9 of the CalARP regulation.    The plant has not had any incidents, which affected offsite receptors in the last 5 years.

The Emergency Response Program

PDI has an emergency response program in place to minimize the effects of accidental releases of regulated subs

tances on employees, the public, and the environment. PDI will be a "non-responding facility" as defined in Section 8.1 of the CCCHSD Guidelines (CCCHSD 1998), i.e. PDI employees will respond to minor incidents. For other than minor incidents PDI has in place an emergency response plan (ERP) in coordination with local emergency response personnel and officials, satisfying the requirements of Title 8 California Code of Regulations (T8 CCR ?3220); the Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (HAZWOPER) regulation T8 CCR ?51921; and Section 2765. 1 (b) of the CalARP regulation.  

PDI maintains a cooperative relationship with both the CCCHSD and the CCCFPD.  The latter will respond to fires or hazardous materials emergencies. PDI will coordinate emergency response with the CCCHSD - Incident Response Team at (925) 646-1112. Selected plant personnel are trained in coordinating emergency evacuation.  During an emergency the EC or designated employees will contact the fire department and security company as necessary. PDI works closely with both the CCCHSD and CCCFPD to prevent regulated chemical releases or fires from occurring and to quickly mitigate either type of emergency.  If possible, emergency evacuation drills will be conducted including plant personnel and the CCCFPD.  The fire extinguisher servicing company will provide fire extinguisher training.  The CCCFPD will perform walk-through inspections of the plant as required. 

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

PDI has conducted PHAs and a seismic assessment  to identify action items that are formulated to reduce the risk (severity or likelihood) of an incident that could reasonably result in an offsite consequence from any of the CalARP regulated chemicals. Sixteen action items were identified.  Fourteen action items have been completed.  Outstanding action items are in progress and scheduled for completion by the end of March 2003.
